It is my work in the women’s movement that validated my humanity, experiences. It is my work in the death/dying sphere that gave me words to shape around complex life experiences. Disenfranchised grief, complicated grief. We can grieve things we chose we never wanted to choose.

For me, though, my choice is filled with difficulty and complexity. I didn’t want to have to choose. Choice can be simple, complex, coerced, unwilling. Life is not black/white. To assume things are simple, goes to plan is naive, ignorant, often filled with hypocrisy, and unkind.

I have been asked, when it comes to having/not having children, “Have I *really* thought about it?” I have. Like a backpack I wear every day, for 26 years now. Constant. We need to trust, respect women’s choices, their autonomy, rights.

I’m so grateful to the pro choice movement and women who have stood up for women’s lives and autonomy. There is still so much stigma, complexity, layers, and isolation to address along the spectrum of reproductive health, choices, lives. We have work to do.

I’m participating in an important project on reproductive choice, @TheChoice_VR - a VR project sharing stories of ppl who experienced an unexpected pregnancy. For me, enormously difficult, necessary, healing. For the 1 in 3 who share my experience: I see you, I’m with you. ❤️ https://t.co/gwHryFdUcj

RT @dana_edits: @LeighNaturkach Nice! It's as important a life decision as any other and should be treated as such!
@dana_edits I love it! You've given me ideas for the men in my life. A friend of mine had a vasectomy party the same way people throw baby showers. Delightful.

Nothing simple abt contraception, repro health, choices, our bodies. Each option comes w/ consequences, impacts. Many of which ppl don't talk/know abt bc are uncomfortable w/ women's bodies, autonomy. It's easy to say "why don't you just". Just stop w/ "just". There is no "just".

I was asked recently about my choices. Did I have doubts. I have only thought about it every. single. day. since I was a kid (given dolls to take care of!) and people told me I would grow up and inevitably want biological children. I knew then. I know now. #TrustWomen

Ugh. The paternalism in reproductive healthcare conversations is nauseating. As though we aren't informed, thoughtful, confident about our bodies and our life choices. That is a terrible experience and I'm sorry that happened. https://t.co/PY6dTBC8VD

That said, the hoops, barriers, stigma, shame, EVERY. DAY. LIFE. LONG. situations, choices, and issues women face in reproductive health are never ending and exhausting. It's just time for men, research, education, healthcare sectors to take up the reins in equal bigger ways.
I'm all for anything that get men actively engaged in reproductive health, choice, decision-making, responsibility, and action. https://t.co/ApeqHhLt0Y
